Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: GOALI: Towards Adaptability to Variations of Renewable Energy in Large Scale Rechargeable Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which is to be conducted by researchers from UNC Charlotte and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI), addresses practical design issues for achieving reliable and uninterrupted operation of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) using harvested ambient energy. The challenge is that these energy sources are often subject to significant spatial and temporal variations. The goal of this project is to create a framework allowing rechargeable nodes to automatically adapt to estimated energy budgets while performing their required monitoring tasks. This adaptive framework is implemented at two levels. The first applies to transmission power control and energy-aware routing; while the second addresses adaptations to temporal variations using an adaptive level-crossing sampling scheme.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research components may be applied to any rechargeable sensor network. The proposed cooperative power control method can potentially solve the overhearing problem, which is a key issue in large-scale wireless sensor networks. The energy-aware and load-balanced routing problems considered here address the unique requirement of meeting specific energy budgets. These network-level solutions are integrated with an adaptive application-level solution designed to overcome the challenges introduced by energy variations.

Broader Impacts: This research addresses a critical issue that is currently of wide interest in the research community. In addition, this project will make educational impacts on UNC-Charlotte students by offering two graduate courses and creating graduate level research projects. This project will bridge the gap between theoretical research and applications and will facilitate stronger research collaborations between the academic and industrial partners involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Harvesting energy from the environment such as solar, mechanical, and electromagnetic sources is a promising technique for achieving long time maintenance-free operation of wireless sensor networks (WSN). However, a key challenge for achieving reliable and uninterrupted operation of WSNs powered by renewable energy is to adequately address the variability of the energy availability from these sources. Renewable energy from environmental sources can have wide spatial and temporal variations due to natural (e.g. weather) and location specific factors (e.g. exposure to sunlight) that can be difficult to predict prior to deployment. This project derives its motivation and specific directions to address this challenge from the team’s experiences in the design and deployment of an experimental WSN for substation monitoring that was initiated by the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI).

The main objectives of this research are to develop statistical models for the variability of energy resources in such rechargeable WSNs based on energy source modeling, energy storage modeling, and source prediction; and utilizing these models to develop algorithms and networking protocols that enable the nodes to adapt their energy consumption to prevent outages. These adaptive algorithms are generally cooperative, requiring distributed control of transmission power, activity cycles, communication channels, and routes selected in the network. The project also addressed design considerations for networks that cannot avoid random node outages due to insufficient energy resources, where special approaches are required to minimize the transmission delay over intermittently connected links.

Key outcomes of this project include: (1) development of an experimental WSN testbed to capture solar irradiance data, which is used in conjunction with weather data to develop an energy prediction model for each node; (2) experimental testing of nickel metal hydride (NiMH) and lithium iron phosphate (LiFeP4) batteries to develop battery storage models and the end-of-discharge () periods for these rechargeable batteries; (3) development of a prototype solar harvesting unit with hybrid storage (super capacitor and LiFeP­4 batteries) with optimum charging control using maximum power point tracking (MPPT) and design considerations for minimizing the charge-discharge frequency of the battery; (4) development of load-balanced energy-aware routing protocols for WSNs; (5) development of joint power control and routing protocols to adapt to variable energy resources in WSNs; (6) development of multi-channel routing protocols to adapt to variable energy resources in WSNs; (7) analysis of the network lifetime of WSNs with optimal power control and channel selection; (8) development of game theoretical approaches for centralized and distributed channel selection, power control, and routing to maximize the network lifetime; (9) analysis of the benefits of cooperative relaying and opportunistic routing in intermittently connected WSNs; and (10) development of mechanisms for minimizing the end-to-end transmission delay in intermittently connected WSNs using transmission diversity and predictive retransmissions.

This project addresses several important problems on effective management of renewable energy resources for achieving long term sustainability of wireless sensor networks, a problem that has been a primary focus of researchers in this area in the recent past. In addition, it involves new theory and practices in distributed computing and analytical models that incorporate mathematical fields such as game theory. The primary impact of this work is on the development of new principles and practices on these issues. Researchers, graduate students, industrial collaborators from EPRI, and a post-doctoral researcher involved in this project gained valuable experience and knowledge that have the potential for generating new knowledge and technologies. Research results are disseminated through conference and journal articles, classroom teaching, summer school, and the project web site. The work performed through this project has provided the PIs with resources and opportunities to educate K-12 students. The PIs have observed that students in this demographic are extremely excited about PV and light detection systems.  The educational experience gained by these students has created an excitement about science and technology that we hope will inspire these students to consider STEM careers.
